title: Solutions with many build dependencies crash OutOfMemory
body:
[This was reported by a customer, who kindly shared memory dumps and some files, but has a proprietary codebase.  I'm trying to anonymize paths and so on, so log snippets may not add up.]

A .metaproj gets [generated](https://github.com/Microsoft/msbuild/blob/639470bfa680e246af02ef11240603b7c1eca657/src/XMakeBuildEngine/Construction/Solution/SolutionProjectGenerator.cs) when MSBuild [determines](https://github.com/Microsoft/msbuild/blob/639470bfa680e246af02ef11240603b7c1eca657/src/XMakeBuildEngine/Construction/Solution/SolutionProjectGenerator.cs#L963) that there are build dependencies defined in the .sln file for a given project.

One of the changes in Update 1 was a fix (#86) for an issue (#69) that bit some customers: the outputs of a project were not passed up to the solution _if that project used solution build dependencies_ (they were passed up if the project didn’t use solution build dependencies).   The fix changed the `.metaproj` "file" generation so that the Build target returned its outputs.

That fix combined with a preexisting problem:  the `.metaproj` put the outputs of all of the `ProjectReferences` it created from the solution build dependencies into the same item group as the outputs of the project it wrapped.  That meant that as we went through the tree, the outputs of each project became its output (typically one DLL), appended to a list consisting of the concatenated transitive closures of outputs for each referenced project.  This grows superlinearly; the list for a high-level project will contain lots of redundant entries for a project that’s depended on commonly throughout the tree.

This is normally just memory-wasteful, but for the large solution (with apparently many solution build dependencies) that our customer had, it spiraled out of control and caused trouble.  A memory dump taken before the crash showed:

```
0:000> !dumpheap –stat
Statistics:
      MT    Count    TotalSize Class Name
…
59e45664 23800184   1047208096 Microsoft.Build.Execution.ProjectItemInstance+TaskItem
Total 101106234 objects
```

23,800,184 TaskItem objects, taking up over a gig of RAM!  There are only 200 projects in this solution.  And this is just a snapshot; the real number kept growing (over 30 GB when using 64-bit MSBuild).

I was able to reproduce this issue on a smaller scale with a three-project solution (all DLLs, 3 depends on 2 & 1, 2 depends on 1) and tweaks to the `.metaproj` generation from 254881f to make the problem obvious.  That shows:

nodes.body:
There are a couple of solutions to this.  At first I considered using [`RemoveDuplicates`](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms164300.aspx) on the list, to keep it from growing unnecessarily.  But then I had what seemed like a better idea.

The generated `.metaproj` files (these are observable by setting the environment variable `MSBUILDEMITSOLUTION=1` and running a build; they are then persisted to disk) currently say:

``` xml
  <Target Name="Build" Outputs="@(ClassLibrary3BuildOutput)">
    <MSBuild Projects="@(ProjectReference)" BuildInParallel="True" Properties="BuildingSolutionFile=true; CurrentSolutionConfigurationContents=$(CurrentSolutionConfigurationContents); SolutionDir=$(SolutionDir); SolutionExt=$(SolutionExt); SolutionFileName=$(SolutionFileName); SolutionName=$(SolutionName); SolutionPath=$(SolutionPath)" SkipNonexistentProjects="%(ProjectReference.SkipNonexistentProjects)">
      <Output TaskParameter="TargetOutputs" ItemName="ClassLibrary3BuildOutput" />
    </MSBuild>
    <MSBuild Projects="D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary3\ClassLibrary3.csproj" BuildInParallel="True" ToolsVersion="$(ProjectToolsVersion)" Properties="Configuration=Debug; Platform=AnyCPU;BuildingSolutionFile=true; CurrentSolutionConfigurationContents=$(CurrentSolutionConfigurationContents); SolutionDir=$(SolutionDir); SolutionExt=$(SolutionExt); SolutionFileName=$(SolutionFileName); SolutionName=$(SolutionName); SolutionPath=$(SolutionPath)">
      <Output TaskParameter="TargetOutputs" ItemName="ClassLibrary3BuildOutput" />
    </MSBuild>
  </Target>
```

That puts the outputs of all of the project references (from the first `MSBuild` task) into the same item group as the outputs of the current project (the second `MSBuild` task), which then becomes the outputs of this project.  That cumulative snowballing is what causes this problem.

We could, instead, avoid keeping the list of the references and return only the outputs of the current project.  In other words, drop the `<Output>` element from the first MSBuild task.  That's what is done, for example, for [`AddMetaprojectTargetForWebProject`](https://github.com/Microsoft/msbuild/blob/0ad816e3044d09a95a92dd234991152933c00545/src/XMakeBuildEngine/Construction/Solution/SolutionProjectGenerator.cs#L1212).  It should also be the behavior seen when no `.metaproj` is required for a given project.

@olivierdagenais, you have more context on this since you filed the bug and contributed the fix (thanks!).  Do you think it would be a problem if we stopped including the transitive closure of references in the returned item, and restricted it to the outputs of the project that's being wrapped?

If that approach doesn't cause any major problems, it's certainly a concise fix: 82280b9.

```
  After project build: D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary1\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary1.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary2\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary2.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary1\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary1.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary3\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary3.dll
```

Going back to [the original Connect report](https://connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/details/1176406/msbuild-targetoutputs-does-not-include-projects-with-explicit-project-dependencies-listed), I see that, in my workaround, when I was collecting the outputs, I immediately called `RemoveDuplicates`, so preventing those duplicates from showing up in the first place is a grand idea.

The question is: are there any items generated by the `AddReferencesBuildTask` that would suddenly disappear from the top-level `TargetOutputs` if we applied the proposed 82280b9 fix?  In other words, would there be a chance of introducing a defect similar to #69, where `TargetOutputs` wouldn't represent the full set of outputs generated by a build?  Specifically, continuing with the 3-project solution repro case above, do we still get `ClassLibrary1`, `ClassLibrary2`, and `ClassLibrary3` returned?

I also have a question on consistency: do the metaprojects return referenced outputs because regular projects do?  Or was the inclusion of referenced outputs just an oversight that wasn't noticed until my fix came along to expose them?

I would be much more comfortable if we had a failing test that was shown to pass with the proposed fix.  Would you mind looking into that?

Thanks!
- Oli

I put up a repo with the example solution I was using: https://github.com/rainersigwald/repro-msbuild-396.

@olivierdagenais When you say "the top-level `TargetOutputs`", do you mean the outputs of building the `.sln` file itself?

Building the `.sln` [from another MSBuild project](https://github.com/rainersigwald/repro-msbuild-396/blob/00a048a524b5d60340852ee5135e72efaf93b7ad/build_sln.proj) produced this output with the current MSBuild (Update 1):

```
Build:
  Solution outputs: D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary1\bi
  n\Debug\ClassLibrary1.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLib
  rary1\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary1.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\
  ClassLibrary2\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary2.dll;D:\work\oo
  m_repro\ClassLibrary1\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary1.dll;D:
  \work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary2\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary
  2.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary1\bin\Debug\Clas
  sLibrary1.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary3\bin\De
  bug\ClassLibrary3.dll
```

Whereas with 82280b9 the list is uniquified (but still complete):

```
Build:
  Solution outputs: D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLibrary1\bi
  n\Debug\ClassLibrary1.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\ClassLib
  rary2\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary2.dll;D:\work\oom_repro\
  ClassLibrary3\bin\Debug\ClassLibrary3.dll
```

Which I think helps resolve my question.  There's no need to worry about the items in the generated `.metaproj` files, because there's no way to reference them!  They're just an implementation detail.  So it should be safe to make that change.

> I also have a question on consistency: do the metaprojects return referenced outputs because regular projects do? Or was the inclusion of referenced outputs just an oversight that wasn't noticed until my fix came along to expose them?

I'm pretty sure it was just an oversight that was unnoticed until the change caused the items to explode in number. It was inconsistent with [`AddMetaprojectTargetForWebProject`](https://github.com/Microsoft/msbuild/blob/0ad816e3044d09a95a92dd234991152933c00545/src/XMakeBuildEngine/Construction/Solution/SolutionProjectGenerator.cs#L1212) which does not return the referenced outputs.

I agree that having a failing test would be useful, but the real error I'm trying to avoid here is the superlinear growth of items with number of projects, which isn't easily expressible in a test.  We should be able to write a test to codify that the approach we take to solve that problem.

This fix will be in Update 2.

If you encounter this, there are a few things you might try:
- Migrate to VS2015 RTM, which didn't have this MSBuild bug (of course, it has _other_ bugs which may make this a bad option).
- Do command-line builds with a private MSBuild that you build that has this fix. Since this bug affects only command-line builds, you should still be able to use Update 1 VS without issue. This is a pain to set up for a whole team, but might help in an effort to upgrade a codebase.
- Remove the project references in the `.sln` in favor of direct MSBuild constructs like `ProjectReference` items or other invocations of the `MSBuild` task.

Thanks for your answers.
Right now we are testing a latest build from the github. Looks good so far.
